articles.headline: Greek Bonds Lure Some, Despite Risk
articles.snippet: Some investors hope to make a fat profit on the expectation that Greece will once again be bailed out.
articles.abstract: Some investors hope to make a fat profit on the expectation that Greece will once again be bailed out.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Greece may never be able to pay off its huge debts, but its bonds, long scorned by investors, are suddenly being gobbled up by hedge funds.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Is Asked to Rule on Health Care
articles.snippet: The unexpectedly quick development makes it all but certain that the court will soon agree to hear one or more cases involving the Obama administration’s health care overhaul.
articles.abstract: The unexpectedly quick development makes it all but certain that the court will soon agree to hear one or more cases involving the Obama administration’s health care overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to hear a case concerning the 2010 health care overhaul law. The development, which came unexpectedly fast, makes it all but certain that the court will soon agree to hear one or more cases involving challenges to the law, with arguments by the spring and a decision by June, in time to land in the middle of the 2012 presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Tiny Cameras, Big Tricks
articles.snippet: The development of the perfect compact S.L.R. continues as Pentax and Nikon introduce two cameras that are jaw-droppingly small yet proficient.
articles.abstract: The development of the perfect compact S.L.R. continues as Pentax and Nikon introduce two cameras that are jaw-droppingly small yet proficient.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why doesn’t everyone buy an S.U.V.? So much space, so much power!

articles.headline: Companies Use Immigration Crackdown to Turn a Profit
articles.snippet: Private security companies have turned the detention of unwanted immigrants into a multinational industry with a history of abuse.
articles.abstract: Private security companies have turned the detention of unwanted immigrants into a multinational industry with a history of abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: The men showed up in a small town in Australia’s outback early last year, offering top dollar for all available lodgings. Within days, their company, Serco, was flying in recruits from as far away as London, and busing them from trailers to work 12-hour shifts as guards in a remote camp where immigrants seeking asylum are indefinitely detained.

articles.headline: Romney Waits as G.O.P. Flirts With Alternates
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s effort to consolidate support from Republican donors and party activists is impeded every time another potential candidate surfaces.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s effort to consolidate support from Republican donors and party activists is impeded every time another potential candidate surfaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican who may have the strongest shot of winning the White House, at least in the eyes of President Obama and his advisers, is Mitt Romney. Now, if Mr. Romney could only persuade Republican voters.

articles.headline: States Putting Hopes in ‘Bottoms Up’ to Help the Bottom Line
articles.snippet: With cities across the country facing their fifth straight year of declining revenues, raising money from people who enjoy a cocktail is becoming an increasingly attractive option.
articles.abstract: With cities across the country facing their fifth straight year of declining revenues, raising money from people who enjoy a cocktail is becoming an increasingly attractive option.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Drink up, America. The government needs the money.

articles.headline: Traveling Tellers, With Electronic Gear, Take Banking to Rural India
articles.snippet: Roving tellers are seen as a promising way to help the rural poor save and protect their money.
articles.abstract: Roving tellers are seen as a promising way to help the rural poor save and protect their money.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOLAD, India — Time was, banks employed armies of human tellers. Later, they replaced many of them with automated teller machines. Now, India is using a hybrid of the two — the human A.T.M. — to expand banking to its vast rural population.
